0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono: Maroteaux-Lamy syndrome: 1 mg/kg IV once weekly infused over a period of at least 4 hours; initial infusion rate (250 mL infusion) 6 mL/hr for first hour; may increase rate to 80 mL/hr for remaining 3 hours; pretreatment with antihistamines with or without antipyretics recommended 30 to 60 minutes prior to start of infusion

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono:
• efficacy in patients younger than 5 years of age has not been evaluated
  • Maroteaux-Lamy syndrome: 1 mg/kg IV once weekly infused over a period of at least 4 hours; initial infusion rate (250 mL infusion) 6 mL/hr for first hour; may increase rate to 80 mL/hr for remaining 3 hours; pretreatment with antihistamines with or without antipyretics recommended 30 to 60 minutes prior to start of infusion

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: specific contraindications have not been determined

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• anaphylaxis and severe allergic reactions, some life-threatening, have been reported during and up to 24 hours after administration; discontinue drug for severe reactions; use caution when rechallenging patients with a history of severe allergic reaction
  • apneic episodes may be exacerbated
  • febrile or respiratory illness, acute; increased risk of respiratory complications during administration; consider delaying infusion
  • fluid volume overload, susceptibility to (eg, weight of 20 kg or less, acute underlying respiratory illness, or compromised cardiac and/or respiratory function); risk of congestive heart failure; monitoring recommended
  • infusion reactions, some serious (eg, laryngeal edema, apnea, respiratory distress, angioedema, and anaphylactoid reaction), have been reported as late as week 146 of treatment; slowing of infusion rate may be necessary; discontinue drug for severe reactions
  • spinal/cervical cord compression (SCC) onset or worsening has been reported; may require decompression surgery; monitoring recommended
  • type 3 immune complex-mediated reactions (eg, membranous glomerulonephritis) have been reported; drug discontinuation may be warranted; monitoring recommended
  • report suspected adverse reactions to the US Food and Drug Administration at 1-800-FDA-1088 or www.fda.gov/medwatch

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Pruritus, Rash (21%), Urticaria
  • Gastrointestinal:Abdominal pain (47%), Nausea, Vomiting
  • Immunologic:Antibody development
  • Musculoskeletal:Arthralgia (42%)
  • Neurologic:Headache
  • Ophthalmic:Conjunctivitis (21%)
  • Otic:Otalgia (42%)
  • Other:Fever with chills, Pain (32%), Shivering (21%)
Serious
  • Immunologic:Anaphylaxis, Complication of infusion, Hypersensitivity reaction
  • Neurologic:Spinal cord compression
  • Renal:Membranous glomerulonephritis
  • Respiratory:Apnea, Bronchospasm, Dyspnea (21%), Edema of larynx, Respiratory distress
  • Other:Angioedema

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Galsulfase, a recombinant normal variant form of a polymorphic human enzyme (N-acetylgalactosamine 4-sulfase), is taken up into lysosomes, thus, increasing the catabolism of glycosaminoglycans (GAG).

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
• General Information
    for IV infusion only
  • Intravenous
    • prepare using low-protein-binding containers; compatibility of diluted solution with glass containers is unknown
    • dilute room temperature vials with NS to final volume of 250 mL; may dilute with 100 mL for patients 20 kg and under or those who are susceptible to fluid volume overload
    • avoid agitation (agitation may denature proteins); do not use filter needle
    • infuse 250 mL infusion at 6 mL/hr for first hour, may increase to 80 mL/hr for remaining 3 hours as tolerated; if diluting in 100 mL adjust infusion rate so total infusion time is over at least 4 hours
    • infuse over no less than 4 hours; may extend to 20 hours if infusion reactions occur
    • administer using a low-protein-binding infusion set equipped with an in-line, low-protein-binding 0.2-micrometer filter
    • store diluted solution in refrigerator unless used immediately; administration must be completed within 48 hours of the dilution

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• improvement in walking and stair-climbing capacity is indicative of efficacy
  • airway patency; consider evaluating prior to initiating therapy
  • acute cardiorespiratory failure; during administration, particularly in patients susceptible to fluid volume overload (eg, weight 20 kg or less, acute underlying respiratory illness, or compromised cardiac or respiratory function); prolonged observation may be required
  • immune complex-mediated reactions; during administration
  • signs and symptoms of spinal or cervical cord compression including back pain, paralysis of limbs below the level of compression, and urinary and fecal incontinence

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• This drug may cause abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, headache, rash, urticaria, pruritus, chills, pain, dyspnea, or pyrexia.
  • Drug may also cause infusion reactions including respiratory distress, laryngeal edema, chest pain, and apnea.
  • This drug may cause severe hypersensitivity reactions (including life-threatening anaphylaxis) which may appear up to 24 hours following infusion.
